facts.text: General election to the Municipal Board of Bareilly in October 1953 from Ward No. 15 with appellant Mangoo Singh and respondent No. 3 Imdad Husain as candidates among others.
Date fixed for filing nominations: October 5, 1953. Both appellant and respondent No. 3 filed nominations on due date.

Scrutiny of nominations: October 7, 1953. Imdad Husain objected to appellant's nomination on ground of disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D of U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916 due to arrears in municipal tax exceeding one year's demand. Objection dismissed by Assistant Returning Officer; appellant's nomination accepted.
Appellant paid Rs. 115-3-0 on October 10, 1953, five days after nomination filing date.
Poll held on October 26, 1953; counting of votes on October 29, 1953. Four persons to be elected; appellant third in list by votes obtained, declared returned candidate. Imdad Husain fifth.
Imdad Husain filed election petition to set aside appellant's election, inter alia on ground of disqualification under cl. g of s. 13-D.

Election Tribunal by judgment dated October 20, 1954 held appellant in arrears exceeding one year's demand to which s. 166 applies, disqualified under cl. g s. 13-D; payment on Oct 10 not wiping off disqualification; no benefit of second proviso to s. 13-D. No bill under s. 166 or demand notice under s. 168 served. Allowed petition, set aside election, declared casual vacancy under cl. a sub-s. 2 s. 25.
Casual vacancy filled by election of third respondent on April 5, 1955.
Appellant filed writ petition under Art. 226 in Allahabad High Court. Chaturvedi J. dismissed on December 10, 1954, agreeing with Tribunal.
Appeal to Division Bench (Special Appeal No. 8 of 1955) dismissed by Agarwala and Sahai JJ. on August 30, 1955.
High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(c) on February 3, 1956 for appeal to Supreme Court.
Next general election due in October 1957.

legal_issues.text: True scope, meaning and effect of cl. g of s. 13-D of the U. P. Municipalities Act, 1916.

petitioner_arguments.text: Disqualification under cl. g s.13-D operates on date of poll (when person is chosen), not nomination; arrears paid on Oct 10, 1953 before poll on Oct 26, so no disqualification attached on poll date.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: cl. g s.13-D; expression 'for being chosen as'

petitioner_arguments.text: Second proviso to s.13-D makes disqualification transient, ceasing as soon as arrears paid; payment on Oct 10 wiped off disqualification subsisting on nomination day, allowing choice on poll day.
Expression 'to which s. 166 applies' in cl. g requires bill presented under s.166 and demand notice under s.168; neither done, so no disqualification.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant disqualified under cl. g s.13-D on nomination date due to arrears exceeding one year's demand; payment after nomination did not wipe off disqualification.

court_reasoning.text: Expression 'disqualified for being chosen as' in cl. g s.13-D attaches from nomination date, a crucial stage in election process; not limited to poll date. Returning Officer scrutinizes for such disqualification at nomination scrutiny per para 22(2) U.P. Municipalities Conduct of Election Order, 1953.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Choice made by series of steps starting with nomination; disqualification at nomination stage prevents being chosen.

court_reasoning.text: Second proviso has no retrospective effect; disqualification subsisting on nomination date not wiped off by subsequent payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disqualification on nomination day does not cease by later payment.

court_reasoning.text: 'to which s.166 applies' describes nature/type of demand (taxes/dues under s.166 cls. a,b,c); does not require bill presentation or demand notice. 'Demand' means amount of arrears/dues, not requiring s.168 notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for bill or notice; phrase qualifies type of arrears.

holdings.text: Appellant disqualified under cl. g s.13-D on day of filing nomination due to arrears exceeding one year's demand; election rightly set aside by Tribunal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chatturbhuj Vithaldas Jasani v. Moreshwar Parashram
precedents_cited.relevance: Disqualification under s.7 Representation of People Act attaches at nomination stage; 'for being chosen' covers election process from nomination.

precedents_cited.case_name: N. P. Ponnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency
precedents_cited.relevance: Election is continuous process; nomination integral part.
Cannot shake off pre-existing disqualification on nomination date by subsequent action before scrutiny/poll.
Disqualified at nomination cannot stand for election even if disqualification removed before poll; avoids uncertainty.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for arrears exceeding one year's demand to which s.166 applies; ceases on payment per proviso but no retrospective effect; nomination scrutiny checks disqualification.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; writ jurisdiction; similar expression 'disqualified for being chosen'.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar disqualification expression interpreted as attaching from nomination.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Municipalities (Conduct of Election of Members) Order, 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Returning Officer refuses nomination if disqualified for being chosen under the Act.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed. Held appellant disqualified under cl. g s.13-D on nomination date; lower courts rightly set aside election. No acceptance of appellant's contentions.

key_quotes.text: 'The choice is made by a series of steps starting with the nomination and ending with the announcement of the election. It follows that if a disqualification attaches to a candidate at any one of these stages, he cannot be chosen.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines when disqualification operates in election process.

key_quotes.text: The wiping off of the disqualification under the second proviso has no retrospective effect.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Clarifies proviso does not cure prior disqualification.

key_quotes.text: 'in arrears in the payment of municipal tax or other dues in excess of one years demand to which section 166 applies'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Exact wording of disqualifying clause interpreted.
